Award.AwardTitle: Causes and Consequences of Dentition Reduction in the Zebrafish Lineage
Award.AbstractNarration: It has long been recognized that the direction of evolution is determined not only by the environments to which organisms are exposed, but also by features of their genetic and developmental programs that constrain the ability to vary. A pattern indicative of such 'developmental constraint' is irreversible evolution, or the failure of lost structures to reappear when organisms return to ancestral environments or behaviors. This project employs an example of irreversible evolution, the reduction of tooth-bearing locations in cypriniform fishes, to characterize the genetic features underlying developmental constraint. Teeth in this group, which includes minnows and suckers, were lost from the mouth and upper throat over 50 million years ago and are retained only on the lower surface of the throat. The lost teeth have never returned, despite the adoption of ancestral feeding modes by multiple lineages of this diverse group. The project will identify genetic changes that occurred in association with loss of teeth in cypriniforms and test the hypothesis that irreversible evolution is the result of accumulated changes in multiple genes and developmental pathways. In addition, genetic engineering approaches will be applied to a common laboratory cypriniform, the Zebra Danio, in an attempt to restore lost teeth. The enhanced understanding of developmental constraint expected to result from the project is relevant to the practical question of whether species will be able to adapt to manmade environmental change or will instead become extinct. In addition to providing research training at the undergraduate, graduate, and post-graduate levels, the project will produce modified fish strains that will enhance courses in Fish Biology and Genetics at the University of Colorado, as well as an exhibit at its Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The extent to which features of the genetic control of development constrain the ability of organisms to adapt to future environments is a fundamental question in Evolutionary Biology. Such limitations on the power of evolution by natural selection are suggested by instances of “irreversible” evolution, in which structures lost in the course of evolution fail to reappear, despite a return to ancestral ways of life. The research supported by this award employed an example of irreversible evolution, the reduction of dentition (teeth) in cypriniform fishes, to explore the developmental and genetic mechanisms underlying constraints on adaptive evolution. Cypriniforms, which include minnows, suckers, and significantly, the Zebrafish model system, are dominant elements of freshwater ecosystems. Teeth in this group are limited to bones of the lower pharynx (throat); dentition in the mouth and upper pharynx was lost over 50 million years ago and never regained, despite the adoption of ancestral feeding modes in multiple lineages.

            Production and/or characterization of transgenic (genetically-modified) Zebrafish possessing alterations in two genetic pathways involved in signaling between cells – Ectodysplasin (Eda) and Wingless-Int (Wnt) – suggested that, surprisingly, the irreversibility of tooth loss in cypriniforms may have different causes in different locations of the body. Teeth were experimentally restored to the upper pharynx by a single genetic change (increased expression of Eda), but this change did not restore other aspects of the pharynx to their ancestral condition. The failure of teeth to return to this location in the course of evolution is therefore likely the result of the complexity of selection required to restore them in an adaptive configuration, rather than constraints on simply generating teeth themselves. In contrast, experimental reversal of the evolutionary loss of Eda or Wnt pathway expression from the mouth was not sufficient to restore teeth to this region, suggesting a constraint on generating them. This constraint likely consists of alteration of multiple pathways during or after the evolutionary loss of teeth in the mouth.

            In contrast to the irreversibility of tooth loss in cypriniforms, the related order Characiformes (similarly diverse and including tetras and piranhas) has experienced tooth loss and reappearance in a number of lineages, particularly on the palate. Overexpression of Eda in a representative of this group, the Mexican Blind Cave Tetra (Astyanax mexicanus), resulted in the frequent appearance of palatal teeth, normally absent in this species. This result not only indicates that the capacity to restore lost structures differs among groups of organisms, but suggests that this variation may explain different degrees of structural diversification among them.

            The most fundamental implication of the research supported by the award is that the degree to which evolution is reversible depends on the structure involved as well of the group of organisms in which it is found. Predicting the capacity for and future direction of evolution is therefore likely to require knowledge not only of predicted environmental changes, but of developmental genetic mechanisms as well.

            Broader impacts of the award include contributions to the research experience of one high school student, seven undergraduate students (including an intern from a foreign university), two graduate students and two post-doctoral Research Associates. The fish facility maintained by the award also made possible a significant project-related educational experience for approximately seventy undergraduate students enrolled in five semesters of the PI’s course in Fish Biology. Outreach activities supported by the award include lectures to a symposium for K-12 teachers on the teaching of evolution as well as contribution to a statewide traveling exhibit by the University of Colorado Museum of Natural History.
